text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- First Deputy Prime Minister Boris Nemtsov confirmed on Tuesday that the shares of six Russian oil producers will be auctioned in the very near future.
- A new mechanism of tax breaks for participants in production sharing agreements seems to have been approved by the government, but it is not clear yet how it is going to work, says the paper.
- The government intends to call on the State Duma to postpone its summer holidays to approve Russia's new tax code.
- New Deputy Energy Minister Sergei Kiriyenko says that first deals in Russia's energy market, which will change existing tariffs and producer-consumer relations, are scheduled for the end of June.
- Aviaagregat, the biggest plane undercarriage producer in Russia, is considering the possibility of cooperation with European plane producers.
SEVODNYA
- The State Duma will discuss on June 11 a new version of Russia's budget, which includes new spending cuts.
- Russia's biggest oil producer, LUKoil, intends to participate in three more projects to develop oil deposits in Azerbaijan.
- Russia's Central Bank is planning to buy all the gold mined in the country, a top bank official is quoted as saying.
- Boris Nemtsov is the first Russian government official, after president Boris Yeltsin, to make public his income and value of his property.
- The Moscow local administration has approved a list of measures to start housing reform in the capital.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- Russia is ready to pull out its peacekeepers from the Georgian region of Abhkazia.
- Tension in the army will grow with further cuts in Russia's budget spending.
- The paper is accusing the West of trying to push Russia out of the Caspian region.
ROSSIASKAYA GAZETA
- Russia frees up pharmaceuticals exports. The government statement is published.
PRAVDA-5
- The paper attacks the mayor of Nizhny Novgorod who may become Boris Nemtsov's successor as regional governor after new elections.
MOSKOVSKY KOMSOMOLETS
- Moscow authorities expect only 70 percent of people to pay for municipal services after housing reform in the capital.
- The paper attacks Boris Nemtsov's reforms in Nizhny Novgorod, where he was previously governor.
-- Tatyana Ustinova, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520.
